We perform a lattice QCD calculation of pseudoscalar meson scattering amplitudes, ignoring quark loops and quark annihilation, and find indications that for sufficiently heavy quarks there is a stable four-quark bound state with JP⁢C=0++superscript𝐽𝑃𝐶superscript0absentitalic-J POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-P italic-C POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:0 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:plus ADDOP:plus POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endJ^{PC}=0^{++} and non-exotic flavor quantum numbers.

The light scalar mesons have defied classification for decades [1, 2]. Some are narrow and have been firmly established since the 1960’s. Others are so broad that their very existence is controversial. Scalar mesons are predicted to be chiral partners of the pseudoscalars like the pion, but their role in chiral dynamics remains obscure. Naive quark models interpret them as orbitally excited q¯⁢q¯𝑞𝑞OVERACCENT:bar ARG:start italic-q ARG:end italic-q\bar{q}q states. Others have suggested that they are q¯2⁢q2superscript¯𝑞2superscript𝑞2OVERACCENT:bar ARG:start italic-q ARG:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-q POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\bar{q}^{2}q^{2}[3] or “molecular” states,[4] strongly coupled to π⁢π𝜋𝜋italic-pi italic-pi\pi\pi and K¯⁢K¯𝐾𝐾OVERACCENT:bar ARG:start italic-K ARG:end italic-K\bar{K}K thresholds.

In this paper we propose a way to shed some light on the nature of the scalar mesons using lattice QCD. Previously scalar mesons have been treated like other mesons: their masses have been extracted from the large Euclidean time falloff of q¯⁢q-q¯⁢q¯𝑞𝑞¯𝑞𝑞OVERACCENT:bar ARG:start italic-q ARG:end italic-q ADDOP:minus OVERACCENT:bar ARG:start italic-q ARG:end italic-q\bar{q}q-\bar{q}q correlation functions with the appropriate quantum numbers. We then study the large Euclidean time falloff of a q¯2⁢q2-q¯2⁢q2superscript¯𝑞2superscript𝑞2superscript¯𝑞2superscript𝑞2OVERACCENT:bar ARG:start italic-q ARG:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-q POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end ADDOP:minus OVERACCENT:bar ARG:start italic-q ARG:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-q POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\bar{q}^{2}q^{2}-\bar{q}^{2}q^{2} correlator, looking for a falloff slower than 2⁢mq¯⁢q2subscript𝑚¯𝑞𝑞NUMBER:2 italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:start OVERACCENT:bar ARG:start italic-q ARG:end italic-q POSTSUBSCRIPT:end2m_{\bar{q}q}, signalling a bound state. We use shortcomings of lattice QCD to our advantage. By excluding processes that mix q¯⁢q¯𝑞𝑞OVERACCENT:bar ARG:start italic-q ARG:end italic-q\bar{q}q and q¯2⁢q2superscript¯𝑞2superscript𝑞2OVERACCENT:bar ARG:start italic-q ARG:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-q POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\bar{q}^{2}q^{2}, we can unambiguously assign a quark content to a state. The heavy quark mass suppresses relativistic effects, which we believe complicate the interpretation of light quark states.

Our initial results are encouraging: within the limits of our computation we see signs of a bound state in the “non-exotic” q¯2⁢q2superscript¯𝑞2superscript𝑞2OVERACCENT:bar ARG:start italic-q ARG:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-q POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\bar{q}^{2}q^{2} channel, namely, the one with quantum numbers that could also characterize a q¯⁢q¯𝑞𝑞OVERACCENT:bar ARG:start italic-q ARG:end italic-q\bar{q}q state (I=0𝐼0italic-I RELOP:equals NUMBER:0I=0 for 2 flavors, the 1 and 8 for 3 flavors). Instead it shows a negative scattering length, characteristic of a repulsive interaction. To obtain a definitive result will require larger lattices and more computer time, but this is well within the scope of existing facilities.

Then we summarize previous lattice calculations. We also review earlier studies of q¯2⁢q2superscript¯𝑞2superscript𝑞2OVERACCENT:bar ARG:start italic-q ARG:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-q POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\bar{q}^{2}q^{2} sources on the lattice.[5, 6] Because these earlier works looked only at one (relatively small) lattice size they were unable to examine the possibility of a bound state. section.h2: II Overview of the light scalar mesons

div.p: In this section we establish the context for our work. First we give a very brief introduction to the phenomenology of the lightest 0++superscript0absentNUMBER:0 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:plus ADDOP:plus POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end0^{++} mesons composed of light (u𝑢italic-uu, d𝑑italic-dd, and s𝑠italic-ss) quarks. We give a sketch of the q¯⁢q¯𝑞𝑞OVERACCENT:bar ARG:start italic-q ARG:end italic-q\bar{q}q and q¯2⁢q2superscript¯𝑞2superscript𝑞2OVERACCENT:bar ARG:start italic-q ARG:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-q POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\bar{q}^{2}q^{2} models for 0++superscript0absentNUMBER:0 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:plus ADDOP:plus POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end0^{++} states and contrast them. More information can be found in Refs. [1, 2] and references quoted therein. Next we summarize existing lattice calculations which relate to the 0++superscript0absentNUMBER:0 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:plus ADDOP:plus POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end0^{++} channel. These fall into two classes: traditional searches for q¯⁢q¯𝑞𝑞OVERACCENT:bar ARG:start italic-q ARG:end italic-q\bar{q}q eigenstates and attempts to learn about low energy π⁢π𝜋𝜋italic-pi italic-pi\pi\pi scattering by studying q¯2⁢q2superscript¯𝑞2superscript𝑞2OVERACCENT:bar ARG:start italic-q ARG:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-q POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\bar{q}^{2}q^{2} sources.

The known 0++superscript0absentNUMBER:0 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:plus ADDOP:plus POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end0^{++} mesons divide into effects near and below 1 GeV, which are unusual, and effects in the 1.3–1.5 GeV region which may be more conventional. Here we focus on the states below 1 GeV. Altogether, the objects below 1⁢GeV1GeVNUMBER:1 GeV1~{}{\rm GeV} form an S⁢U⁢(3)f𝑆𝑈subscript3fitalic-S italic-U OPEN:( NUMBER:3 CLOSE:) POSTSUBSCRIPT:start f POSTSUBSCRIPT:endSU(3)_{\rm f} nonet: two isosinglets, an isotriplet and two strange isodoublets. The isotriplet and one isosinglet are narrow and well confirmed. The isodoublets and the other isosinglet are very broad and still controversial.

The physical object appears narrow because the K¯⁢K¯𝐾𝐾OVERACCENT:bar ARG:start italic-K ARG:end italic-K\bar{K}K channel is closed over a significant portion of the object’s width. No summary this brief does justice to the wealth of work and opinion in this complex situation.

The other light scalar mesons are known as broad enhancements in very low energy s-wave meson-meson scattering. The enhancements are universally accepted, but their interpretation is more controversial. At the lowest energies only the π⁢π𝜋𝜋italic-pi italic-pi\pi\pi channel is open. The π⁢π𝜋𝜋italic-pi italic-pi\pi\pi s-wave can couple either to isospin zero or two. The I=2𝐼2italic-I RELOP:equals NUMBER:2I=2 (e.g. π+⁢π+superscript𝜋superscript𝜋italic-pi POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:plus POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-pi POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:plus POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\pi^{+}\pi^{+}) channel shows a weak repulsion in rough agreement with the predictions of chiral low energy theorems.[9] The I=0𝐼0italic-I RELOP:equals NUMBER:0I=0 channel shows a strong attraction: the phase shift rises steadily from threshold to approximately π/2𝜋2italic-pi MULOP:divide NUMBER:2\pi/2 by ∼800similar-toabsent800RELOP:similar-to NUMBER:800\sim 800 MeV before effects associated with the f0subscript𝑓0italic-f POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUBSCRIPT:endf_{0} complicate the picture. This low mass enhancement in the π⁢π𝜋𝜋italic-pi italic-pi\pi\pi s-wave is the σ𝜎italic-sigma\sigma meson of nuclear physics and chiral dynamics. Recent studies support the existence of an S-matrix pole associated with this state at a mass around 600 MeV, which we will refer to as the σ⁢(600)𝜎600italic-sigma OPEN:( NUMBER:600 CLOSE:)\sigma(600).[2, 10] The π⁢K𝜋𝐾italic-pi italic-K\pi K s-wave is very similar to π⁢π𝜋𝜋italic-pi italic-pi\pi\pi. The exotic I=3/2𝐼32italic-I RELOP:equals NUMBER:3 MULOP:divide NUMBER:2I=3/2 (e.g. π+⁢K+superscript𝜋superscript𝐾italic-pi POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:plus POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-K POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:plus POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\pi^{+}K^{+}) channel shows weak repulsion. The non-exotic I=1/2𝐼12italic-I RELOP:equals NUMBER:1 MULOP:divide NUMBER:2I=1/2 channel shows relatively strong attraction. [1] Other couplings of these objects (the σ𝜎italic-sigma\sigma can couple to K¯⁢K¯𝐾𝐾OVERACCENT:bar ARG:start italic-K ARG:end italic-K\bar{K}K and the κ𝜅italic-kappa\kappa can couple to η⁢K𝜂𝐾italic-eta italic-K\eta K) are unknown because the relevant thresholds lie above the states. The large widths of these states reflect their strong coupling to the open decay channels π⁢π𝜋𝜋italic-pi italic-pi\pi\pi and π⁢K𝜋𝐾italic-pi italic-K\pi K respectively.

The conventional quark model assigns the 0++superscript0absentNUMBER:0 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:plus ADDOP:plus POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end0^{++} mesons to the first orbitally excited multiplet of q¯⁢q¯𝑞𝑞OVERACCENT:bar ARG:start italic-q ARG:end italic-q\bar{q}q states. As in positronium, 0++superscript0absentNUMBER:0 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:plus ADDOP:plus POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end0^{++} quantum numbers are made by coupling L=1𝐿1italic-L RELOP:equals NUMBER:1L=1 to S=1𝑆1italic-S RELOP:equals NUMBER:1S=1 to give total J=0𝐽0italic-J RELOP:equals NUMBER:0J=0. The 0++superscript0absentNUMBER:0 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:plus ADDOP:plus POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end0^{++} states should be very similar to the 1+±superscript1absentplus-or-minusNUMBER:1 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:plus ADDOP:plus-or-minus POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end1^{+\pm} and 2++superscript2absentNUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:plus ADDOP:plus POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end2^{++} q¯⁢q¯𝑞𝑞OVERACCENT:bar ARG:start italic-q ARG:end italic-q\bar{q}q states that lie in the same family. These are very well known and form conventional meson nonets (in S⁢U⁢(3)f𝑆𝑈subscript3fitalic-S italic-U OPEN:( NUMBER:3 CLOSE:) POSTSUBSCRIPT:start f POSTSUBSCRIPT:endSU(3)_{\rm f}). Since they have a unit of excitation (orbital angular momentum), they are expected to be quite a bit heavier than the pseudoscalar and vector mesons. Most models put the q¯⁢q⁢0++¯𝑞𝑞superscript0absentOVERACCENT:bar ARG:start italic-q ARG:end italic-q NUMBER:0 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:plus ADDOP:plus POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\bar{q}q~{}0^{++} mesons along with their 2++superscript2absentNUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:plus ADDOP:plus POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end2^{++} and 1++superscript1absentNUMBER:1 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:plus ADDOP:plus POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end1^{++} brethren around 1.2–1.5 GeV.

The vector mesons are best known, but the pattern is equally apparent in the 2++superscript2absentNUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:plus ADDOP:plus POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end2^{++} or 1++superscript1absentNUMBER:1 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:plus ADDOP:plus POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end1^{++} nonets. The strange isodoublets are heavier because they contain a single strange quark (e.g. the K∗superscript𝐾∗italic-K POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:ast POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endK^{\ast}). The final isosinglet is heaviest because it contains an s¯⁢s¯𝑠𝑠OVERACCENT:bar ARG:start italic-s ARG:end italic-s\bar{s}s pair (e.g. the ϕitalic-ϕitalic-phi\phi). div.p: We conclude that if, as our results suggest, there is a bound q¯2⁢q2superscript¯𝑞2superscript𝑞2OVERACCENT:bar ARG:start italic-q ARG:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-q POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\bar{q}^{2}q^{2} state in the non-exotic channel, then this means that with two flavors, the I=0𝐼0italic-I RELOP:equals NUMBER:0I=0 channel is bound, and with three flavors both the 1 and 8 are bound. Once quark loops and annihilation diagrams are included, the 1 and 8 will split apart. Unquenched lattice calculations will be needed to see if they remain bound.

In our lattice calculations, we work in the quenched (valence) approximation, and use Symanzik-improved glue and quark actions. This means that irrelevant terms (𝒪⁢(a),𝒪⁢(a2)𝒪𝑎𝒪superscript𝑎2caligraphic-O OPEN:( italic-a CLOSE:) PUNCT:, caligraphic-O OPEN:( italic-a POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end CLOSE:){\cal O}(a),{\cal O}(a^{2}), where a𝑎italic-aa is the lattice spacing) have been added to the lattice action to compensate for discretization errors.

Improved actions are crucial to our ability to explore a range of physical volumes using limited computer resources. Because most of the finite-lattice-spacing errors have been removed, we can use coarse lattices, which have fewer sites and hence require much less computational effort: note that the number of floating-point-operations required even for a quenched lattice QCD calculation rises faster than a-4superscript𝑎4italic-a POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:4 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:enda^{-4}.

Improved actions have been studied extensively [7, 19, 20, 21, 22], and it has been found that even on fairly coarse lattices (a𝑎italic-aa up to 0.4⁢fm0.4fmNUMBER:0.4 fm0.4~{}{\rm fm}) good results can be obtained for hadron masses by estimating the coefficients of the improvement terms using tadpole-improved perturbation theory. For the energy differences that we measure, we find that the improved action works very well. There are no signs of lattice-spacing dependence at a𝑎italic-aa up to 0.4⁢fm0.4fmNUMBER:0.4 fm0.4~{}{\rm fm}, so as well as greatly reducing the computer resources required, it enables us to dispense with the extrapolation in a𝑎italic-aa that is usually needed to obtain continuum results.

Our lattice glue and quark action parameters are summarized in table 1 and are described in detail in Ref. [7]. For the glue we use a Lüscher-Weisz (plaquette and 2×121NUMBER:2 MULOP:times NUMBER:12\!\times\!1 rectangle) action [20, 21]. We measured the lattice spacing by NRQCD calculations of the charmonium P-S𝑃𝑆italic-P ADDOP:minus italic-SP\!-\!S splitting, using the experimental spin-averaged value of 458⁢MeV458MeVNUMBER:458 MeV458~{}{\rm MeV}.

For the quarks we use a D234 action, which includes third and fourth derivative terms as well as an improved clover term. All the coefficients in the action are evaluated at tree level in tadpole-improved perturbation theory [23], using the mean link in Landau gauge to estimate the tadpole contribution. We work at a quark mass close to the physical strange quark: the pseudoscalar to vector meson mass ratio mP/mVsubscript𝑚𝑃subscript𝑚𝑉italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-P POSTSUBSCRIPT:end MULOP:divide italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-V POSTSUBSCRIPT:endm_{P}/m_{V} is 0.76.

We collected data at two lattice spacings, a=0.40𝑎0.40italic-a RELOP:equals NUMBER:0.40a=0.40 and 0.25⁢fm0.25fmNUMBER:0.25 fm0.25~{}{\rm fm}. For our fits to eq. (1) in Sect. IV we used the average.

In the quenched approximation the masses of q¯⁢q¯𝑞𝑞OVERACCENT:bar ARG:start italic-q ARG:end italic-q\bar{q}q states like those shown in Fig. 2 are roughly independent of mPsubscript𝑚𝑃italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-P POSTSUBSCRIPT:endm_{P}. Note especially that the masses are smooth as they cross the threshold, 2⁢mP2subscript𝑚𝑃NUMBER:2 italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-P POSTSUBSCRIPT:end2m_{P}. In contrast, we believe that the q¯2⁢q2superscript¯𝑞2superscript𝑞2OVERACCENT:bar ARG:start italic-q ARG:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-q POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\bar{q}^{2}q^{2} state we may have identified is strongly correlated with the P⁢P𝑃𝑃italic-P italic-PPP threshold when the quark mass is large, and departs from it in a characteristic way as the quark mass is reduced.
